question: Examine the progress of the Civil Disobedience Movement in the countryside.
answer: From the cities, the Non Cooperation Movement spread to the countryside. [0] (i) In the countryside, rich peasant communitieslike the Patidars of Gujarat and the Jats of Uttar Pradesh were active participants. [1] (ii) They participated in the Movement because they suffered the most due to the economic depression. As their cash income disappeared, they found it impossible to pay the government's revenue demand. [1] (iii) They demanded a reduction in revenue, but the government refused to do so. This led to a widespread resentment. These rich landlords participated in the boycott programmes, and refused to pay revenues. For them, the fight for Swaraj was a struggle against high revenues. [1] (iv) But they were deeply disappointed when the movement was called off in 1931 without the revenue rates being revised. So when the movement was restarted in 1932, many of them did not participate. [1] (v) The poor peasantry also participated on a large scale in a hope that their unpaid rent to the landlords will be remitted. [1]

question: Analyze the ways through which people of different communities developed a sense of collective belonging in India.
answer: (i) This sense of collective belonging came partly through the experience of united struggles and growing anger among people against the colonial government. [1] (ii) But there were also a variety of cultural processes through which nationalism captured people‘s imagination. [1] (a) The identity of the nation symbolised in a figure or image of Bharat Mata created through literature, songs, paintings, etc. [1] (b) Movement to revive Indian folklore to enhance nationalist sentiments. question: How did the ideology of ‘liberalism’ affect the Europe in early nineteenth century? Explain.
answer: The ideology of liberalism allied with nationalism in the following ways: [0] (i) Liberalism stood for freedom for individual and equality of all before law. [1] (ii) It emphasised on the concept of government by consent. [1] (iii) It stood for the end of autocracy and clerical privileges. [1] (iv) It believed in a constitution and representative government through Parliament. [1] (v) The coming of the railways further linked harnessing economic interests to national unification as it helped stimulate mobility [1]
